name: Tomato Late Blight
description: Caused by the fungus Phytophthora infestans. Appears as pale green, water-soaked spots on leaves.

stages.Advanced: Lesions enlarge, turning brown to black, with a white moldy growth on the underside of leaves.

causes: High humidity, cool temperatures, and prolonged leaf wetness.
risk_factors: Poor air circulation, overhead watering, and leaving infected debris in the soil.
preventive_measures: Ensure proper spacing, water at the base of the plant, rotate crops, and remove infected plants promptly.
solution: Apply fungicides containing mancozeb or chlorothalonil. Ensure proper spacing for air circulation and avoid overhead watering.

name: Powdery Mildew
description: A fungal disease that affects a wide variety of plants, appearing as white powdery spots on leaves and stems.

stages.Initial: Small, white, powdery spots on the upper surface of leaves.
stages.Advanced: The powdery spots spread to cover entire leaves, stems, and sometimes flowers and fruit. Leaves may turn yellow and fall off.

causes: Fungi in the order Erysiphales. Spores are spread by wind.
risk_factors: High humidity at night and low humidity during the day. Crowded planting and poor air circulation.
preventive_measures: Choose resistant varieties, ensure good air circulation, and avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen.
solution: Apply fungicides like potassium bicarbonate, neem oil, or sulfur. Prune affected areas to improve air circulation.

name: Black Spot
description: A common fungal disease of roses, characterized by black spots on the leaves.

stages.Initial: Small black spots with fringed margins appear on the leaves.
stages.Advanced: The spots enlarge and the surrounding leaf area turns yellow. Infected leaves often drop prematurely.

causes: The fungus Diplocarpon rosae, which overwinters on infected leaves and stems.
risk_factors: Wet, humid conditions. Overhead watering that leaves foliage wet for extended periods.
preventive_measures: Water at the base of the plant, provide good air circulation, and remove and destroy infected leaves.
solution: Apply fungicides containing chlorothalonil or myclobutanil. A mixture of baking soda and horticultural oil can also be effective.

name: Ringworm (Tinea Corporis)
description: A common fungal infection of the skin. Not caused by a worm.

stages.Initial: A red, itchy, scaly patch on the skin.
stages.Developed: The patch develops into a distinct ring-shape with a raised border.

causes: Direct contact with an infected person or animal, or contact with contaminated items like towels or clothing.
risk_factors: Weakened immune system, excessive sweating, and participating in contact sports.
preventive_measures: Keep skin clean and dry, avoid sharing personal items, and wear loose-fitting clothing.
solution: Apply over-the-counter antifungal creams, lotions, or powders like clotrimazole or miconazole for 2 to 4 weeks. Keep the skin clean and dry.

name: Chickenpox (Varricella)
description: A highly contagious viral infection causing an itchy rash with small, fluid-filled blisters.

stages.Prodromal: Fever, headache, and sore throat before the rash appears.
stages.Eruptive: Rash begins as small red spots that turn into itchy blisters (vesicles).
stages.Crusting: Blisters dry out and form scabs, which eventually fall off.

causes: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Spread through direct contact or by inhaling airborne droplets.
risk_factors: Not being vaccinated, having a weakened immune system, or never having had chickenpox.
preventive_measures: Vaccination is the most effective prevention.
solution: Treatment focuses on relieving symptoms. Calamine lotion and oatmeal baths can soothe itching. Acyclovir may be prescribed for severe cases.

name: Common Cold
description: A mild viral infection of the nose and throat (upper respiratory tract).

stages.Incubation: 1-3 days after exposure to the virus.
stages.Symptoms: Runny or stuffy nose, sore throat, cough, congestion, slight body aches or a mild headache, sneezing, low-grade fever.

causes: Most commonly caused by rhinoviruses. Spread through airborne droplets or contact with infected surfaces.
risk_factors: Weakened immune system, exposure to crowds, and being in cold weather (indirectly).
preventive_measures: Frequent hand washing, avoiding touching face, and staying away from sick individuals.
solution: Rest and fluids are key. Over-the-counter medications like decongestants and pain relievers can help manage symptoms. There is no cure for the common cold.

name: Canine Distemper
description: A contagious and serious viral illness with no known cure that affects dogs, and certain species of wildlife.

stages.Initial: Fever, loss of appetite, and watery discharge from the eyes and nose.
stages.Advanced: Vomiting, diarrhea, and neurological symptoms like seizures and paralysis.

causes: Caused by the canine distemper virus (CDV), which is spread through airborne exposure or contact with infected bodily fluids.
risk_factors: Unvaccinated puppies and dogs are at the highest risk. Crowded environments like kennels can also increase the risk of transmission.
preventive_measures: Vaccination is the most effective way to prevent canine distemper. A series of vaccinations is recommended for puppies, followed by regular boosters.
solution: There is no cure for canine distemper. Treatment is supportive and aimed at managing symptoms, including providing fluids to prevent dehydration and medications to control seizures and vomiting.

name: Rabies
description: A deadly viral disease that affects the central nervous system of mammals, including humans.

stages.Prodromal: Changes in behavior, fever, and licking at the bite site.
stages.Paralytic: Paralysis of the throat and jaw muscles, leading to coma and death.

causes: Rabies virus, transmitted through the saliva of an infected animal, usually via a bite.
risk_factors: Exposure to wild animals, especially bats, raccoons, skunks, and foxes. Not vaccinating pets.
preventive_measures: Vaccinate all pets (dogs, cats, ferrets). Avoid contact with wild animals.
solution: There is no cure for rabies once symptoms appear. Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), including a series of vaccine shots and rabies immune globulin, can prevent the disease if administered promptly after exposure.

name: Feline Leukemia Virus (FeLV)
description: A retrovirus that infects cats and weakens their immune system, making them susceptible to other infections and diseases.

stages.Abortive: The cat's immune system eliminates the virus.
stages.Regressive: The cat's immune system controls the virus, but it remains in the body in an inactive state.
stages.Progressive: The virus actively replicates and causes disease.

causes: Feline leukemia virus, spread through saliva, nasal secretions, urine, feces, and milk from infected cats.
risk_factors: Living with infected cats, outdoor access, and not being vaccinated.
preventive_measures: Vaccination, testing new cats before introducing them to a household, and keeping cats indoors.
solution: There is no cure for FeLV. Treatment is supportive and focuses on managing secondary infections and symptoms. Antiviral therapies may help in some cases.
